channel.title: I Learnt
channel.description: Things I have learnt over time ...

item.title: Simple versus Complex
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: It is very difficult to develop a simple piece of software and keep it simple.

item.title: Simple task breakdown
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: We needed to plan the work for the next quarter for the infrastructure team and in doing so came up with a simple way to breakdown the work.

item.title: Bringing the menu to life
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: We recently visited a local Indian restaurant and they had an interesting way to explain the dishes on the menu.

item.title: The One Percent Exercise
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: At a recent off-site we ran a simple group exercise that will hopefully make a big difference to the success of the company

item.title: The Cuckoo's Klein Bottle
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: When I was at university, a long time ago, one of the books I really enjoyed was "The Cuckoo's Egg" by Clifford Stoll.

item.title: Missing images
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I hadn't updated my blog for a while so I thought I would write a short post about The Keeper Test. That is when all the images suddenly stopped displaying on this blog.

item.title: 8 minutes
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Can a friend ask you for a chat when they really need one?

item.title: The Keeper Test
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: It is that time of year where performance and salaries are reviewed. In my new role it is the first time I have been part of this. I came across a very timely article that aligned nicely with one of the steps in our process.

item.title: Emotions as beach balls
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Do you suppress your emotions?

item.title: Ambiphone
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: When I am working and need to focus I like to have music in the background.

item.title: One Life
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: For the first time in ages we had a family night at the cinema to see the film "One Life". It is unusual for my wife and I to agree on a film to watch, let alone the kids as well!

item.title: Pushing The Limits
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: A lot of coding jobs can involve fairly "normal" tasks - create a page, write to and read from a database, add a new field to this screen. These tasks have been done numerous times by numerous developers around the world in different flavours.

item.title: The straw that broke the camel's back
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description:
There is an idiom "the straw that broke the camel's back" which, according to Wikipedia, describes

a minor or routine action that causes an unpredictably large and sudden reaction due of the cumulative effect of other small actions.

item.title: Speeding up Windows PC
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: My dad is pretty tech-savvy (he was an electronic engineer) however he was having problems with how long it took his Windows PC to become usable.

item.title: Piling and Organisation
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I enjoy doing jigsaws once a year, over the Christmas period.

item.title: Useless Things You Remember
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: During a team call this morning, one of the engineers mentioned about the useless things he still remembers and how it would be good if the brain would clear them out.

item.title: How I learnt to run my own personal AI
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: By now most people have tried or at least heard of ChatGPT. It is now relatively easy to run your own AI instance on your own machine.

item.title: How I learnt about not compromising
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I have just finished re-reading the book The Spark, a fictional account of a sports agent and his journey to learn about Cirque de Soleil from the inside.

item.title: How I learnt to pick ideas that win
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I come up with lots of ideas for potential applications, businesses, stories and random other things.

item.title: Capturing decisions and those involved
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: My role has changed recently to include another team. This has also included more interaction with other areas of the business and also the management team.

item.title: Breaking things down
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: A task can often look too big to tackle. It can become very daunting even in deciding where to start.

item.title: Decisions with a cost
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Sometimes a decision comes with a cost, a sacrifice.

item.title: Simple tips can make a difference
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: When I grew up I had an old 35mm Praktica camera that was given to me. I purchased some lenses for it and mostly used it to take pictures of the Somerset cricket matches I went to watch.

item.title: Turbo Pascal is 40
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Turbo Pascal is 40 years old and it had a big impact on the direction of my career.

item.title: Assumptions can be dangerous
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: There is a quote "A backup is not a backup unless you have recently performed a restore from it"; I got to find this out the hard way.

item.title: Document your house
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: We have manuals and guides for the software we use. We have a manual for the car we drive. Why not the house?

item.title: Oh no second
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: An oh no second is that moment in time when you realise that you have done something potentially catastrophic and your stomach turns to mush with the dread and realisation.

item.title: The unknown future of software developers
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: The role of the software developer is set for a major upheaval over the coming years.

item.title: The cost of AI
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: There is a rush at the moment to add AI to everything with a fear that if you don't then you will be left behind.

item.title: Foundations lead to structure
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Foundations are important and need to be correct and strong before you build anything.

item.title: Abstract art
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I have never understood abstract art. I have tried.

item.title: Favourite books
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: The top shelf of books in my study has the books that have had the most impact on me or that I have enjoyed reading the most.

item.title: The joy and dilemma of reading
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I read a lot of books. Last year I read over 50 books and this year I am heading towards 40 books.

item.title: What is different?
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description:
Every Monday morning as part of our stand up meeting we ask a "question of the day". A designated victim person chooses a question that each team member gets to answer. This week the question that was asked was:

What do you like about our company that is different from other places you have worked?

item.title: Letting go is hard
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Last weekend our daughter started on the next part of her life journey. We dropped her off at Exeter University as she is about to embark on a four year adventure studying psychology.

item.title: Istrian holiday notes and tips
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: We recently spent just under two weeks visiting Croatia and in particular the Istrian peninsular. These are my notes and thoughts from the holiday.

item.title: Always agreeing
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: When interviewing a potential candidate recently I asked them the difference, in their opinion, between the way a consultant/contractor engages with a company and a full time employee.

item.title: Advice, warnings and genetic algorithms
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: In the Knowledge Project podcast with Adam Robinson there is an interesting observation about warnings.

item.title: Avoiding regrets
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: When my daughter was at nursery I missed a show she was in. Unknown to me, she had the leading role and I missed it because of a work meeting.

item.title: I rely on RSS
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I rely on RSS (Really Simple Syndication) to keep me up to speed on what is happening in the world.

item.title: Life changer
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I was fortunate enough to meet someone who dramatically changed my life but didn't know it. And when I met them I didn't even get the chance to speak to them or say thank you.

item.title: Rites of passage
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: "A rite of passage is a ceremony or ritual of the passage which occurs when an individual leaves one group to enter another."

item.title: Valuing existing customers
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I wonder if there are a group of people in companies that set the prices for their products that still like the concept of bartering? They seem to like the negotiations of trying to find the highest price an existing customer will stay with them.

item.title: Public/Private keys introduction
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I recently had to try and explain to some non-technical colleagues how part of our system works. This involved giving them a very quick overview of public/private key cryptography. So I thought I would summarise it here.

item.title: The Online Safety "Bull"
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Imagine you wanted to send a message to a friend. The message has sensitive information so you want to send it securely.

item.title: The right question
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I've written a lot about questions, and answers.

item.title: Pressure and stress
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: We often equate pressure with stress and vice versa.

item.title: Ignoring the bad
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Nearly every technology can be used for good and bad. Quite a bold statement but something I believe is true.

item.title: Mind - not time - management
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Being productive is sometimes more about mind management than time management.

item.title: Photos on a map
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: It is possible to see a (heat)map of all the photos you have taken in Google Photos.

item.title: Viable is important
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: "Minimum Viable Product", or MVP, is a phrase that has become common place. It gained fame through the Lean Startup book and the work of Eric Ries.

item.title: The best and worst
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I have been to see two musicals in London in the last few months - one was the best and one was the worst I have ever seen.

item.title: Cut to gain
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: In 2018, Andrew Barnes' company, Perpetual Guardians, permanently introduced a four day week (FDW). The staff would get 100% pay but work 80% of the time as long as they hit 100% of their productivity goals.

item.title: Do your best
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: My daughter finishes her A Level exams today. Let's just say she can't wait to get them over and done with. She has worked incredibly hard over the last month or so; in fact over the last two years.

item.title: School work experience
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: In most UK schools we have the concept of work experience.

item.title: Bad estimation
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Estimation is a very difficult task - depending on what is being estimated.

item.title: Delete your meetings
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Could you be bold enough to delete all the meetings in your calendar?

item.title: Start of the Ashes
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I watched a day, well some of a day, of Ashes cricket between England and Australia in 1989.

item.title: Thank a teacher
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Teachers can make a huge difference - in both a positive and a negative way.

item.title: Be surprised
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: When I am developing software I build an internal mental model of how I expect things to work. As I learn more I tweak that model - or if it is not working as I expect then I tweak the code to match the model I have. Over time that model grows and evolves.

item.title: Art - theft, forgery and wow
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I am not an artist and I have limited knowledge of art but I recently enjoyed a TV series and I am currently reading a book related to the subject.

item.title: An artist in the family
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: My grandfather was a skilled artist - well in my eyes he was. He also taught art at secondary school.

item.title: The restaurant of mistaken orders
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I came across this YouTube video with an intriguing title - "The Restaurant of Mistaken Orders". Having recently read a lot about hospitality this piqued my interest.

item.title: How might we
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: The simple use of the phrase "how might we" can open up design discussions and improve company mission statements.

item.title: Organised chaos
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I have mostly been working from my dad's workshop for the last week.

item.title: Value other peoples time
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Maybe it is my upbringing but I always try to be on time for things.

item.title: A hot desk in north Devon
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I have been visiting my parents in Devon recently and working from there. It makes a nice change of scenery - I can work during the day and visit places out of hours as well as obviously spending time with them.

item.title: Stop reading ...
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I read a lot but this post is about being encouraged to stop reading.

item.title: Design for the few
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: How do you design a product that is going to be used by a lot of people?

item.title: Beware of the normal
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: It is easy to take things and people for granted.

item.title: What makes a good holiday?
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: We are not a family that likes to just sit on the beach. We may spend a little time doing that - everyone needs to relax - but we tend to prefer doing and seeing things.

item.title: Helping habits happen
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: In the book Excellent Advice for Living, Kevin Kelly identifies the importance of habits.

item.title: Picking a path
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: There is a lot of different advice when it comes to making a decision and picking a path.

item.title: Moving from 'can't' to 'learning to do'
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: It is easy to decide that you can't do something.

item.title: Don't be afraid to ask the stupid question
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Ego and the fear of how we appear to others can get in the way sometimes. We don't want to appear stupid so we avoid finding out things we don't know.

item.title: Show seconds in the Windows 11 taskbar
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I noticed the other day that my wife's laptop was showing seconds in the time in the taskbar but my laptop was not; a very handy feature to have.

item.title: Focus on the question
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Questions are underrated. Lots of people focus on answers when they should be focussing on identifying the right question to ask.

item.title: The legend of Trevor
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: It is amazing how one small thing can set the tone or the culture going forward.

item.title: The upstream butterfly effect
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: The butterfly effect famously states that the flapping of the wings of a butterfly somewhere in the world can impact the weather on the other side of the world - a small change can have a huge impact over time.

item.title: Downstream to upstream
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: How do we move from solving downstream reactive problems to upstream proactive solutions?

item.title: Cultural fit versus contributor
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: When we recruit people we are obviously looking at their ability to perform the role on offer but we are also looking at how well they will work with the team.

item.title: Spending coins
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: This is a great description of the difference between an introvert and an extrovert.

item.title: End of an era
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description:
"There's something that the Kop wants you to know

The best in the world, his name is Bobby Firmino

Our number nine

Give him the ball and he'll score every time

Sí Señor

Pass the ball to Bobby and he will score"

item.title: Negative intelligence
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: It is very easy to do something negative to try and show how intelligent we are.

item.title: Blame me
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: We often hear the phrase "it's a no blame" culture - but do we really live that?

item.title: Why gossiping can impact you
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: In the book 59 Seconds by Richard Wiseman he talks about an effect called "Spontaneous Trait Transference".

item.title: Sweets can make a difference
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: My daughter sometimes works as a waitress at the local Pizza Express. If she has a good night then sometimes she can earn more in tips than her wages (although that is not very often).

item.title: Should meetings be asynchronous?
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Every couple of weeks we have a meeting called "FriYay". Based on a rota, each department has the opportunity to own one of these and present what they are celebrating.

item.title: How I use Obsidian
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I thought it might be useful to document how I use Obsidian.

item.title: My most used Obsidian plugins
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I have started using Obsidian a lot. One of the things that I really like is the ability to add community plugins to add functionality as required.

item.title: Should I edit my photos?
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I am not a photographer. However I like thinking that I can take a good photograph.

item.title: Surprisingly familiar
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: In the TED talk The four-letter code to selling anything Derek Thompson explains about a concept called MAYA.

item.title: Letters Live
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I once heard that the way you can tell if something is actually funny is that it causes you to laugh out loud even when you are by yourself. It is much easier to laugh at something when surrounded by others.

item.title: No more school
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Today is my daughter's last official day at school - they have a party for about an hour tomorrow so that doesn't count.

item.title: Prototyping is not always coding
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Part of my current role is prototyping new features and algorithms to determine if and how they will work. It's nice to do some hands on coding still.

item.title: Expectations and comparisons
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Some times expectations are met, or exceeded, and sometimes they fail to be met.

item.title: Which bird are you?
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I am a lark.

item.title: Alarms lost in the noise
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Adding an alert or alarm for a situation you need to monitor should be a good thing but sometimes, depending on how it is done, it can actually make things worse or at a minimum not work as expected.

item.title: Learning without action
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Should all learning require an action?

item.title: What would you attempt if you knew you could not fail?
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I have a fear of failure ... to an extent. I guess I am a little risk averse.

item.title: Story bank
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Life is made up of stories.

item.title: There is more to it
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Growing up I was a big fan of Jean-Michel Jarre.

item.title: Giving second chances
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Sometimes people need a second chance.

item.title: Don't tell your friends
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Andy Weir is one of my favourite writers. I have read most of his books. However he claims he doesn't like the writing process.

item.title: Going above and beyond
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: What does going above and beyond look like?

item.title: The difference between service and hospitality
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: What is the difference between service and hospitality?

item.title: The space elevator
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: This is a beautiful interactive webpage to illustrate the height/altitude of different things and how a potential future space elevator would relate to them.

item.title: Podcasts with bookmarks
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I listen to quite a lot of podcasts. I have been using Spotify but recently switched, most of the time, to using an app called Snipd.

item.title: How do you define a good hotel?
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: A recent stay at a hotel got me thinking about what defines a good hotel?

item.title: Lex, an AI assisted editor
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Lex.page was one of the first AI assisted editors available.

item.title: Uncovering the Benefits of AI Search Engine Perplexity.ai
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I have tried to avoid writing about AI as everyone seems to be doing it however I have found one site that is pretty usable and actually seems to work quite well.

item.title: Don't steal the towels
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I recently stayed at a hotel and a small sticker in the bathroom caught my attention.

item.title: Load balancing algorithms
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description:
Sometimes you come across a post that is so brilliantly put together you have to share it - and I am not talking about any of my posts.

This post walks the reader through the different algorithms used by load balancers and the pros and cons of each approach. A load balancer takes requests and splits them between different processes (or servers) that can handle them. It's aim is to balance the load between them, hence its name.

item.title: A local version of AWS
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: One of the things that has deterred me from doing much personally in the cloud has been the potential cost.

item.title: Music to focus
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: When I am working I like to have music in the background to help me focus. I find, like a lot of people, that it needs to be music without lyrics most of the time.

item.title: Hyper-V on Windows 11 Home
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I am dabbling with .NET Maui and developing an application for Android. Tied to that I have just changed laptop. On my previous laptop I had Windows 11 Pro but the new one has Windows 11 Home.

item.title: VS Code for any Github repository
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I came across this tweet and had to try it.

item.title: My Free Blog Setup
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I thought it was worth documenting my current setup for this blog. Most of it is automated and it costs me nothing to host it.

item.title: Homemade do not disturb light
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: My current role means I work full time from home - which is great. The commute is easier, the food is better and having flexibility is great.

item.title: The origins of Space Invaders
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: When I was at school they had a building which was mainly for the use of those doing their O Levels (the old name for what is now GCSE examinations). There were only two reasons I would get to go to the building: one was for music lessons as for some reason the music department was located there. The second was to attend the weekly youth night they held for each year group.

item.title: Finding your dads work in a museum
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: It is an interesting experience to find the work your dad did being exhibited in a museum.

item.title: The seagull data centre algorithm
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Could studying the habits of seagulls lead to better cloud computing approaches?

item.title: Fatherly wisdom
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description:
Today my daughter turns 18 years old. Wow, time flown has by.

One of her friends is putting together a present that includes letters from her friends and family. This gave me the wonderful opportunity to write her a letter reminiscing about her life and telling her how proud of her I am - and also giving her advice for the future.

item.title: The first pictures from space
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: It turns out the first pictures taken from space were not initially planned.

item.title: Numbers for managing teams
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Sometimes you come across an article that makes you think. The article, Numbers To Know For Managing Software Teams, made me do that.

item.title: Annual life review
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I recently had the scenario where I had to use up a few days holiday before they would expire. I decided to hire and cottage and go walking. Unfortunately due to a stomach bug this didn't go quite as planned however the other aim was to conduct a life review and assess what I wanted to achieve over the coming year.

item.title: Free learning list
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: The freelearninglist.org website identifies the best education resources for each type of platform.

item.title: Picking ideas
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I have a file with 400+ ideas for businesses, products, books, etc. So finding ideas is relatively easy. However validating and picking ideas is more of a challenge.

item.title: Decide who decides
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: As many of my posts start, I was listening to a podcast. This was a startup founder who was talking about the company she started with a partner and how they handled decisions where the two of them didn't agree about something.

item.title: Strategies for starting something new
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Most people struggle with the blank page and starting something new. This episode of the podcast Spark & Fire has snippets from interviews with 5 different people and how they start something new or overcome writers block.

item.title: Twitter to Mastodon
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: It definitely feels like Twitter is slowly dying.

item.title: The world in photos
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I recently came across two different websites that allow you to look at the world through photos in two completely different ways.

item.title: A Tale of Three Experiences: Customer Service Up Close
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Last week I experienced a range of customer service related to a new sofa we bought. It's clear how much difference it can make.

item.title: Fix default Android emulator not showing in Visual Studio 2022
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I am working on a Maui application in my spare time and Visual Studio has this annoying habit of not showing the default Android emulator when I load the project. I could go through the hassle of creating a new emulator each time but that is painful and slow.

item.title: Reducing Build Size
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I have been developing a Maui application as a side project and on the whole it has been a fun process. It is still very buggy and there are some pain points however it seems to work. One aspect I haven't liked is the size of the build artefacts - they are huge if you have multiple projects.

item.title: Information - Organisation - Application
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description:
"Put everything you know out for free but in a random order".

In the School of Greatness podcast with Rory Vaden he proposes that you should do exactly the above to build your brand and your opportunities.

item.title: Solving a Dell laptop freezing
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I have a Dell XPS13 laptop and it developed this really annoying habit of randomly freezing for a few seconds and then carrying on as if nothing had happened. It quite often happened in the middle of a work call which made it pretty much unusable.

item.title: Generational Mindsets
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: In a recent article/tweet the author commented on how all the photos taken by their child looked awful. However they realized this was down to a different generational mindset.

item.title: Learnings from my jobs
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I have had lots of jobs during my life and I think I can identify at least one thing I have learnt at each of them. I usually know it is time to move to a new role if I no longer enjoy it or I am no longer learning something new.

item.title: JAS goals
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: About fifteen years ago, Casey Treat spoke at our church about goal setting. He explained that a lot of people set a goal of reaching a certain weight and he said the problem with that occurs when you reach that weight.

item.title: Why? Not no
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: One of my favourite podcasts is Hanselminutes by Scott Hanselman. I have been listening to it probably longer than any other podcast. He recently interviewed Roberta Arcoverde from Stack Overflow. She talked about how the architecture of the Stack Overflow site is very different from most other large sites in that it is a self hosted monolithic application.

item.title: So what do you do?
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: It is a classic way people start a conversation. Some people meet, they exchange a few pleasantries and then they ask "and, so what do you do?" And each person then takes turns, hopefully if someone doesn't just keep talking, explaining what their job is.

item.title: Getting quieter to get louder
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Austin Kleon wrote an article about how we can get used to anything. Something is new and exciting but before too long it becomes the normal and we are no longer excited by it. It seems to be part of our nature.

item.title: High value low engagement versus high engagement low value apps
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Most mobile apps, and websites to an extent, seem to be driven by how much they can get the end user to use or engage with them; the more usage the better.

item.title: Work in 2030
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: There are two camps of people where I work; those who want to return to the office and those who want to remain working remotely. The former group tend to be those whose work involves spending most of the day talking to people (the "business" side of the company). The latter group tend to be those whose work is mostly focussed around thinking - or have family and enjoy the balance this approach affords. I fall into the latter camp on both counts.

item.title: Future proofing
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: It is always tempting when buying or designing things to plan for the future; to add features that make your design or purchase "future proof".

item.title: How to fix Sony Bravia/Sonos sound stops working
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: We have a Sony Bravia television connected to a Sonos Beam which in turn is linked to a couple of Sonos Ones. They have been working fine for quite a while but suddenly lost sound.

item.title: Capturing memories
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: A PhD student has created a way to capture conversations with hospice patients that their relatives can play back and listen to at any time later.

item.title: Preparation meets opportunity
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Another podcast ... I was listening to Guy Raz interview General David Petraeus on the "Wisdom from the top" podcast. Towards the end he made the observation that luck is where preparation meets opportunity. This implies the more prepared you are then the more "lucky" you will be when opportunities arise.

item.title: Installing a payphone
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: This is quite an amazing article about how someone ended up installing an actual old style payphone in their house.

item.title: Last House Standing
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: We had a guest speaker at church on Sunday, the son-in-law of our pastors. He spoke on the subject of "Last House Standing" - based on Matthew 7:24-27, the wise and foolish builders.

item.title: Saving lives through design
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: A few years ago I had to do first aid training as part of the mandatory training for the youth football team I coached. This included learning how to use a defibrillator - something you obviously hope to never have to use. I was impressed how well it explained each step of what you need to do.

item.title: Creativity modes
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I recently discovered the Huberman Lab podcast so I have been working through the back catalogue. I was listening to one on creativity and mentioned that creativity is effectively taking existing elements and rearranging them in novel ways. It highlighted that there are two parts to creativity - creating/discovery and linear/implementation.

item.title: Tiny Projects
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Like lots of people, especially developers, I have a long list of potential business/app ideas that sit around and gather dust. Some of them are just impractical, some I don't have the skills to do but the biggest constraint is time and the battle with all the other commitments life throws at you.

item.title: Are you considering time sensitivity?
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Somethings in life are time sensitive and some are not. A business opportunity may be time sensitive in that it will only be a success when certain things are aligned or maybe new technologies are available.

item.title: Kenneth Goanascis
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Many years ago when I ran an engineering team for a consultancy we would get calls almost every day from recruitment agencies trying to pitch their services to us.

item.title: WeWork versus IWork
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description:
A colleague just spent the day at a WeWork and commented on how badly named it was.

It's official, WeWorks are so hard to work in. Ironic really.

item.title: Is fear of failure really the fear of judgement?
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: In the Alchemist by Paulo Coelho there is a quote “There is only one thing that makes a dream impossible to achieve: the fear of failure.” This ties in nicely with an observation from Gino Wickman in a podcast with Lewis Howes (School of Greatness) recently. He observed that in a lot of cases the fear of failure is really a fear of judgement.

item.title: Is it time to renew your novice permit?
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: When I feel I am no longer learning I know it is likely time for me to either look at how my current role can change or time to look for a new role.

item.title: How can a forcing function help me achieve things?
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: In the David Perell podcast with Daniel Gross they also talked about forcing functions. They started by discussing why Israel seems to be so strong in the tech industry and whether their unique circumstances may be the cause. They talked about how they approach problems as they are forced to deal with the consequences if they don’t - compared to other nations that try to solve problems as they may be impacted by them at some point in the future.

item.title: Is the level too hard?
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I have been interested in the use of gamification to achieve things for a while. Given my son’s love of the Xbox I have also wondered if it could be used in some way to help him study.

item.title: Building a collection of habits
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I have followed the writing of David Perell for a while and recently listened to some of the podcasts he has recorded. Somehow I stumbled on one with Daniel Gross. Towards the end of the podcast David mentions his aim to build the largest collection of habits he can.

item.title: Commuting to my office at home
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description:
Scott Hanselman posted a tweet with the following tip:

Here's a tip that my remote team does - When you get up in the morning, if you're willing and able, try COMMUTING to your home office! Go for a circle around your neighbourhood and arrive back home to your home/remote office! It psychologically marks the start and end of the day.

item.title: How to find a missing Sonos
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: We recently purchased a Sonos Beam and hooked it up to 2 Sonos Play Ones we already had. It works really well and we are really pleased with it. We expected to mostly use it with the TV but have found ourselves using it more and more to play music. However every few days the Sonos app seems to lose the setup. The TV still works with it but the application does not show the system - this is very frustrating.

item.title: Professionalism and the extra mile
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: We had been planning to have a large garden summerhouse built for a number of months and we were finally in a position to do so. After a lot of research we decided to engage a local company as we liked the style of building they produced and the price was also competitive.

item.title: Openness, discussions and success
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I work very closely with two colleagues - and have done so for a number of years. Together we have experienced some serious ups and downs in the company we work for and also personally. We have each reached a point where we were close to leaving; we have each had something happen in our lives where the others have supported us.

item.title: AI breaks the game of hide and seek
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: This is a really fun video where an AI is given a version of the game of hide and seek and each team has to learn ways to win - either by finding the other team or by not being found.

item.title: The growing power of influencers
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Quite often I will come across long articles and either put off reading them or just skim through their content. This article is well worth taking the time to read as it completely changed my views on where the media industry is heading. My notes here do not do it justice but will hopefully give you enough to encourage you to read it in full.

item.title: The loosely held product roadmap
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: In a recent article by Ryan Singer, Options, Not Roadmaps, he explains why he doesn't use roadmaps - he uses options instead.

item.title: New ways to generate ideas online
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: There are a lot of sites that claim to be idea generators. Most of them turn out to be just a button you click that slings together a bunch of random words that are meant to then become a prompt to generate ideas.

item.title: Questions to ask yourself before you buy
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Sometimes it is very easy to buy things just for the sake of it. We get that rush when either we bring the item home or it is delivered. It is easy to form an addiction to that feeling.

item.title: Exposing the beauty in a problem
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I was recently reminded of this great quote:

item.title: Fractional talent as an alternative pool of resources
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: At the startup I work for we used to have a full time HR person. These were in the days when the expectation was that we would have explosive growth and the company would "at least double in size every few months". Unfortunately that is not the way it played out - we are still making good progress but have much more realistic growth plans.

item.title: Committing time to stand out from the crowd
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: There is a famous quote that asks how you eat an elephant and the answer is one bite at a time. It can be very daunting when attempting something new especially if it is potentially a large task. However it is impossible if you don't take the first step.

item.title: How behaviour can shape the culture
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Andrew Cherrie is the pastor of Home Church. In a recent sermon entitled "7 lessons from 7 years at Home Church" he gave the following quote:

item.title: Solitude and conversations lead to great ideas
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: There was a tweet recently by Sahil Lavingia that stated

item.title: How we recharged the team with a fallow week
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Due to the ongoing COVID situation the team had been struggling to stay focussed and motivated. The inability to go out, the lack of change of scenery and the sameness every day has been taking its toll. To try to address this we actively encouraged them to take time off - which, given the limitations on travel, was less appealing than it normally would be.

item.title: How to change your day with meeting plans
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I recently had a day where I had about 10 different meetings - all on different subjects. I knew that I would struggle to be productive in each of them if I turned up for them unprepared and had to switch subjects each time.

item.title: When your WPF menu alignment is wrong
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I had a very weird problem where my menus on a WPF application were dropping down to the left instead of the normal to the right.

item.title: How to easily implement successful remote team retrospectives
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: As part of our processes we regularly hold retrospectives. We used to do this all in a room with post-it notes - a fairly traditional approach. We would set up 4 areas: Liked, Longed, Learned and Lacked and proceed to plaster post-it notes over the different sections. Once everyone had finished we would organise each section into themes and then discuss and agree actions.

item.title: A first encounter with sketchnoting
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: One of the talks I attended at the Microsoft Build conference was called "Sketchnoting 101" and given by Nitya Narasimhan. It gave a very high level view of the approach and how anyone can quickly pick it up.

item.title: Rethinking conferences in a remote only world
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I recently attended the fully virtual Microsoft Build conference. There is no way I would have been able to attend the real "physical" conference due to the location, financial commitment and time required however this gave me an opportunity to benefit from something normally out of my reach.

item.title: Increasing productivity using a simple magnetic whiteboard
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Whenever I work I am always jotting down things on pieces of plain paper next to me - this could be things to do, ideas, random thoughts, planning for meetings, etc.. Every week or so I do a cull of this stack of paper and then start on a new piece of paper.

item.title: A quick fix for missing Gmail notifications on Android phones
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I occasionally stop getting Gmail notifications on my Google Pixel 2XL android phone. I later find that I have a whole bunch of emails that I had missed. I am not sure what causes it however I have found a way to make it work again.

item.title: The fastest way to switch Gmail accounts on Android phones
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Using Gmail on Android it is possible to support multiple email accounts. The normal way you can change which account you are looking at is by pressing on the account picture in the top right hand corner and then selecting the user.

item.title: Finally a to-do app I use ... Microsoft To Do
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I have tried numerous to-do applications in the past; from the very simplest to the all-singing, all-dancing applications and they have never stuck. I used them for a week or so and realised a month later that I hadn't used them for a while.

item.title: Yet another productivity book summaries site
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I came across an excellent site for summaries of productivity books. There are a lot of sites out there that provide summaries however the quality of the video summaries is excellent and seems to be updated fairly frequently.

item.title: Boost productivity with meeting free days
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: It is very easy for your work week to become a random collection of meetings - all with different attendees and different agendas. For developers in particular this can cause a huge hit on productivity as their day becomes disjointed and they are unable to stay focussed for the longer periods they need for their work.

item.title: The ultimate paper airplane database
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: This site contains a collection of easy to follow designs for paper airplanes. Something for the "kids" to try.

item.title: A simple addition to every meeting
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: We have a lot of remote meetings as most of our team work a significant amount of time from home. Face to face meetings are much better for some types of meetings - especially workshops and retrospectives. As the level of expected collaboration increases the more it favours face to face interactions.

item.title: Speed up in the long term by slowing down in the short term
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: On most projects there is a tendency for someone involved to become the "expert" in one or more areas. As they become comfortable and more knowledgeable in an area they will naturally gravitate to picking up tasks related to it. The need to deliver as quickly as possible can also drive this as the person who knows most is likely to be the person who can do the work quickest.

item.title: A remote family breakfast
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Someone I work with mentioned that each week he takes time to have coffee with his mum. This might sound quite normal but there are two parts that stand out for me.

item.title: Watch an octopus dreaming
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Obviously we have no idea whether the interpretation in the video is correct however I love they way the octopus changes colour and shape as it "dreams".

item.title: Goggles give back sight
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: This short clip is pretty remarkable. A young woman lost most of her sight due to a brain tumour. All she has left is a small blurry circle in her right eye. With the use of some AR goggles and some very clever tech she was able to read for the first time in years - very moving.

item.title: Sleep is your superpower
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: This is one of the scariest videos I think I have ever seen. It is not a horror movie or a thriller - it is a talk about the impact sleep has on the body and in particular the impact a lack of sleep has. This includes increasing the risk of cancer, decreased brain function and reduced immune system. I am seriously reconsidering how I "do" sleep after watching this!

item.title: Even more book summaries
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I read a lot of books - a bit less at the moment as I commute less - but still probably more than most people. However there are so many books I would like to read I can't read them all. I still prefer to read the full book but sometimes book summaries are useful - either to get the key concepts or as a reminder of what I have previously read.

item.title: Tackle the difficult problems first with #MonkeyFirst
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I was listening to the audiobook for "Questions Are the Answer" by Hal Gregerson and it mentioned an approach used by the X lab at Alphabet nicknamed "MonkeyFirst".

item.title: Consensus 2019 - Conference Notes
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: These are my notes from attending the Consensus 2019 conference in New York - there is a good chance that some of the notes I made are incorrect.

item.title: Lazy programmers can be the most productive
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: There is often a work culture that you should be busy all the time - if you are a programmer you should always be typing and producing code. Programming is a mental process and so requires thinking. Sometimes a little thought upfront saves a lot of pain and work down the line.

item.title: A clear desk helps avoid being the bottleneck
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I really like Seth Godin's blog - I could easily link to his posts every day - however occasionally a post really stands out for me. A recent post called Bottlenecks had an interesting observation that was a different way of thinking about them.

item.title: Technical debt is like Tetris
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: This article uses a really neat analogy with Tetris for illustrating the impact of technical debt. Leaving gaps is akin to leaving technical debt in the code base and makes subsequent changes more difficult or slower to ship.

item.title: Empowering problem solvers - not offering solutions
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: There is a natural reaction for people when faced with a problem to offer solutions. This can be especially true for managers.

item.title: It always pays to leave well
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: When someone leaves a company there are two sides to it.

item.title: The battle of real versus artificial deadlines
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: This excellent article looks at the different types of deadlines and the impact they have. The key point for me, and not something I had seen previously defined, is the distinction between real and artificial deadlines:

item.title: How to run a planning workshop
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: We have just completed a two week exercise with the whole development team to identify, design and estimate the next phase of work. It started as an organic process as we found the best way to do this and then developed into a repeatable process for the latter functionality.

item.title: Places to name things
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: This one is just for future reference for me that I may find useful one day - a website full of resources that may be useful for naming things.

item.title: Do we really need that meeting? - the forgotten costs
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: We had a meeting recently with 16 people on the video conference call. Due to poor planning and technical issues it took nearly half an hour to decide to postpone the meeting. That is eight man hours wasted - a whole day of work!

item.title: The value of throwing code away
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: We had a discussion at work about "throw away" code. One of our developers was very against developing any code that would be thrown away afterwards. He referred to this as a waste. In my view sometimes the biggest gain can be in developing code that is meant to be thrown away. It can be used to try things and, more importantly, learn things that can shape the code that is kept. This article sums it up much more eloquently than I can.

item.title: From 5 whys to why now?
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I have used the "5 whys" approach multiple times to get to the root of some question. This article advocates adding a time dimension to the decision. Not only should we consider why we are doing something, we should also consider why we are doing something at a specific point in time. It also twists this around and suggests we should consider "What is the danger of not doing this right now?" - what would we lose or miss?

item.title: How to identify real gurus and experts
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: This is an old post (March 2009) that someone retweeted but still holds true on how to work out if an expert is really an expert. It also is a guide how not to fall into common traps that so-called experts fall into.

item.title: Creating 3D animations from a 2D photo
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: This is a pretty amazing demonstration of animating an aspect of a 2d photo. This even includes pulling out bodies and animating them moving away from their original scene.

item.title: Black Mirror - technology ethics and can it be used for wrong?
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Nearly every technology that has been developed has been used for both good and bad. Developments that look like they could have a massive impact on civilization have usually also spun off a side effect that has a detrimental effect. This could be the latest technologies such as genetic engineering and artificial intelligence or older technologies such as the automobile.

item.title: Antilibrary - should I finish the book I am reading?
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I read a lot of books and once I start reading a book I normally finish it. This article proposes that it may be more valuable to have a bunch of books that are unread. Not sure I completely buy in to the proposition that "Read books are far less valuable than unread ones" however maybe I won't feel so guilty buying a book and then leaving it unread.

item.title: Setting up Github SSH
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Just a reminder of the starting point for setting up SSH with Github so I don't have to keep looking for it each time.

item.title: Git - what to do when it goes wrong
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: This has a great summary of what to do when things go wrong when using Git. Added here so I know where to look in moments of panic.

item.title: The secret history of Ctrl+Alt+Del
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: The background to why the famous "three finger salute" was chosen to be so difficult to do.

item.title: Sometimes to learn you also need to do
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I am back on the learning Scala trail and it is clear that just reading books and articles or watching videos won't cut it. It needs to be hands-on coding.

item.title: Scala + Sbt + Docker quickly
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I am currently starting to learn Scala (to add to a myriad of other languages I have programmed in over my career). We are also in the process of "dockerizing" our application. So I wanted to try for myself getting a simple Scala application running in Docker.

item.title: Abolish performance reviews
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I have never been a fan of performance reviews. It may have been down to the way they were implemented at the places I worked however they never seemed to achieve what they were set out to do. The review would usually consist of going over the "achievements" for the past period and then setting a bunch of artificial goals for the next period. The only time these new goals were actually consulted was in the run up to the next review.

item.title: Abandoning the baggage of Agile
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I have worked with various flavours of "Agile" over numerous years. These have ranged from the very formal where everything is done by the book to more ad-hoc versions where different parts are cherry picked or in most cases done because people think they should be done.

item.title: Travel the world with the geographic game - GeoGuessr
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: This is a very simple idea for a quiz. It drops you in a random place somewhere in the world and you use Google StreetView to work out where it is. If you are lucky you end up in a town or city, sometimes you end up in the middle of nowhere. It is amazing how much you can work out by looking at the flora or a random signpost.

item.title: The legacy vulnerability of the Internet
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: This article documents developments over the last ten years at all layers of the network stack. It also highlights how vulnerable the current Internet is.

item.title: A simple change can lead to a big Impact
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: A simple change in message can lead to a big impact.

item.title: In a distributed system ... there is no now
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: This paper is a discussion around the issues faced by distributed systems when dealing with time, ordering and failures. This is particularly relevant with the work I am doing at the moment designing a very large distributed system that will need to scale massively.

item.title: A Hitchhiker’s Guide to Consensus Algorithms
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: This is a summary of a number of consensus algorithms currently being used in the Blockchain space. The most common at the moment is Proof of Work however this is slowly being replaced by other approaches that are more performant and don't use all the Earth's energy.

item.title: REST API Guidelines
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: This is here for future reference - a very good set of guidelines for REST APIs.

item.title: The accelerated pace of image processing developments
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: There are some amazing things happening with image processing at the moment. I remember my graphics class at university 25 years ago and the primitive, by comparison to now, image processing algorithms we had to code. Oh how things have moved on.

item.title: A personal link to 'The Mother Of All Demos'
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: There is a video of a demonstration given by Doug Engelbart in 1968 which is commonly referred to as "The Mother Of All Demos". In the demo, he demonstrates a lot of technologies for the first time together that are common place today and some which we haven't even achieved properly now:

item.title: Working from home boosts productivity
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I am fortunate with my current role that I am able to work 2-3 days per week from home. This saves me about 2.5 hours of commuting time per day as well as about £2000 per year.

item.title: Armada by Ernest Cline
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Took me a little while to get into this book. It starts out in a school where a pupil spots a spaceship from his favourite video game. This then moves on to it being a precursor to an invasion by the aliens from the video game and the game itself was actually put together as training so the players could pilot drones in the war. A slightly surreal concept but pretty well executed. The "twist" with the main characters dad is a bit contrived but overall not a bad read - enjoyed it more as it went along. Not as good as Ready Player One.

item.title: The bosses who change our lives
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I have been very fortunate in my career to have some exceptional bosses that have had a massive impact on my career.

item.title: Zero to One by Peter Thiel
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I had read a lot of good things about this book and it had sat on my Kindle for a long time. Really enjoyed the first half of the book but thought the second half was more focused on things that weren't relevant to me. There were some statements made that were clearly opinions but were stated as facts. Overall a bit disappointing.

item.title: The unseen impact of the little trade-offs
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I found this article to be a very astute observation that it can be all the "little trade-offs" that can add up to cause issues. The article highlights it from the perspective of a leader who can make small decisions, usually around putting something off or taking a short cut, that can add up to impact their work and those around them.

item.title: An entrancing dance with just the hands
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: My daughter loves dancing. She was entranced by this (so was I). The effort this must have taken to choreograph and the level of control between both the dancers is impressive.

item.title: The amazing evolution of the English alphabet
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: A simple chart showing how the English alphabet evolved and how we ended up with what we have. It is particularly interesting how the Roman alphabet changed to become the English alphabet.

item.title: Making the explanation of distributed systems fun
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I love the way this article explains some of the key issues with designing distributed systems and how to solve them. It uses the illustration of a theme park and the rides - very clever and a fun read, which is unusual for a distributed systems article!

item.title: A MacBook touchscreen for only $1
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I don't own, and have no intention of owning, a MacBook as I own a touchscreen Windows laptop however this approach to make it support touch is genius. They use a mirror at the top of the screen and some image processing to work out where the finger is. They can determine if the finger is actually touching the screen by whether it is touching its reflection - very clever lateral thinking.

item.title: It is 'just' ...
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: It is very easy to make assumptions about a subject you know well and others may not. You will have knowledge you have learnt over time that you perceive is so simple or obvious that others should just know it - forgetting that once you too had to learn it. This article sums it up really well with the word ... "just".

item.title: How to track down a missing international payment
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I was due to be paid for some work earlier this month and the payment was from a foreign bank account into my account in GBP. The payment was made two weeks ago but never turned up in my account. After numerous phone calls with my bank and a lot of help from the CFO of the company I am working for (thanks Mario) we eventually managed to locate the payment.

item.title: Good Strategy/Bad Strategy by Richard P. Rumelt
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I've had this book a while but never got around to reading it properly. One of my colleagues at work was listening to the audio version of it and recommended it. This was an excellent read and very relevant to what is happening at the company I am working at at the moment. For me the key takeaway was that what most people call strategy is not actually strategy but vision or goals. Strategy is setting a direction and what needs to happen to achieve it. The observations about the approaches of Walmart and Cisco were particularly good.

item.title: Privacy should be our choice
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: A great quote from this podcast by 23andMe Co-Founder and CEO Anne Wojcicki ...

item.title: Pi
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: This page is devoted to maths and in particular pi. The answer to the second question on this page is unexpected and I love the energy the maths teacher brings to the class in the video. I had some okay maths teachers but never one quite like this.

item.title: The term 'Blockchain' is meaningless
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: There seems to be no single clean definition of what "Blockchain" actually means. There are a lot of woolly statements, several of which are clearly either wrong or too narrowly focused. This article goes into some of the different definitions and why they are wrong and then the implications of this from a business but also a legal perspective.

item.title: The ultimate broken mental barrier - the four minute mile
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I had never seen the original footage of Sir Roger Bannister running the first four minute mile. His narration of the race really adds to it as well.

item.title: Using AI to find code problems
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Ubissoft have introduced a tool that "uses AI" to identify potential coding issues when the developer commits code. They claim it can detect a significant number of errors and even suggest solutions in some cases. There will always be some errors that it will not be able to identify, for example where the implementation doesn't match the requirements, however this approach could have a significant impact on the amount of time spent debugging. And it should improve over time as it learns more potential errors.

item.title: Blackout by Marc Elsberg
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: This story documents one scenario that could happen when the nightmare happens of a massive power cut across Europe. It starts with a number of threads and weaves them well together. It follows an Italian as he realizes it is a terrorist attack on the smart power meters. This destabilizes the power grid which takes down most of the grid across Europe. A second attack targets the power plants. This leads to a power cut across Europe that lasts days and the storyline of how they track down the cause and the perpetrators.

item.title: Reducing the team size to deliver
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: A project was struggling to deliver in time and the project manager resolved it by reducing the team size where the typical approach is to increase the team size. This decision was based on the overhead of communication and Brooks Law.

item.title: Developer platforms must listen to developers in order to grow
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: This is an excellent study on why developers are so important to a platform. At the moment we are developing a platform and we have been trying to get this message across to the business side of the company. This article backs up what we have been saying.

item.title: How do crypto-currencies work?
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: A very simple introduction to how Bitcoin works ... using a stuffed penguin!

item.title: Leaders Eat Last by Simon Sinek
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I really liked Simon Sinek's other books but didn't get into this one as much - don't get me wrong, it is still an excellent read and you can learn a lot.

item.title: Don't let status change the conversation
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I am probably like most people in that when I meet someone who I deem to be important the way I deal with them changes. It introduces a more reserved interaction with more careful responses.

item.title: Unorthodox leadership by letting others drive
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Steve Kerr, the coach of the Golden State Warriors basketball team, took an usual step recently by allowing his players to coach instead of him. He felt that things had become a little staid and wanted to shake things up ... it worked - they won by their highest margin of the season. Sometimes leadership is knowing when to step back.

item.title: Making technology less manipulative
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: This was an excellent podcast on the ethics behind some of the decisions being made about technology today. The whole talk is excellent and thought provoking however for me one part (about 27 minutes in) stood out:

item.title: Learning from terminally ill children
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I am going to try and enjoy the small things in life and focus more on those close to me; something that is not always easy when caught up in the hustle and bustle of life.

item.title: The DIY table maze marble roll
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Some people have way too much time on their hands.

item.title: Designing Your Life: How to Build a Well-Lived, Joyful Life by Bill Burnett and Dave Evans
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I was really looking forward to this book as I had listened to a podcast where they explained the ideas behind it. The two authors run a design course in Stanford that gets massively oversubscribed and has a huge impact on those who take it by looking at life as a design problem. The aim is to come up with lots of possible routes for your life that could be awesome and then design a path to achieve one of them. If that doesn't work you can use the same approach to look for new opportunities. I have not yet made the time to do the exercises and these are absolutely key to getting the most out of it.

item.title: Stunning nature photographs
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: These nature photos are absolutely stunning. Some people have a gift for photography ... and I am not one of them.

item.title: Dancing without sound
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: My daughter loves dancing - always has done - whether it is street, contemporary or ballet. However she faces none of the challenges the dancers (and musicians) in this video face. I won't spoil it here ... just watch.

item.title: The simple idea of free water refills
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: This is such a simple idea and could potentially have a huge impact if it takes off - cafes and pubs filling up water bottles for free.

item.title: Smart glasses you might actually wear
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Intel have just announced a new set of smart glasses that don't look stupid. Admittedly the functionality is a lot more limited that other offerings however these look a lot more normal than them. It provides very limited functionality to display a small red image in the lower part of the wearers vision. Cleverly it also disappears when the user is not looking down.

item.title: Extending a wifi network with a TP-Link RE650
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I had a very unusual setup for the network for my office. The office is situated a floor above and at the opposite end of the house to where the main router is located. A fully wired connection is not an option at the moment due to concrete floors and limited access to roof voids.

item.title: Ma’agalim - Jane Bordeaux
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: This is a beautiful music video. Watch it all the way through and carefully watch what happens to some of the characters.

item.title: Professionals do everything necessary - not just the fun bits
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: This article defines the difference between a professional developer and an amateur as:

item.title: The Kubernetes Book by Nigel Poulton
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: At the moment I am having to get up to speed on a bunch of technologies relating to "DevOps". This includes Kubernetes. I borrowed this book from a colleague and read it over the course of two days commuting. It provides a very good high level overview of all the main concepts of the platform.

item.title: When The Game Was Ours by Jackie MacMullan, Larry Bird, and Magic Johnson
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: On 12th June 1984 I was on a family holiday in the US. We had spent three weeks travelling around Florida and then up the east coast to finally end up in Boston. During the day we had a guided tour of the city and we were told that it was game seven of the NBA finals that night between the Boston Celtics and the Los Angeles Lakers.

item.title: Using crazy socks to make an impact
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: This is a great article about a small business that is growing rapidly and run with a smile on their faces. John and his dad started a business to sell crazy, fun socks and it has gone from strength to strength. I also like the 5% of sales to the Special Olympics and the socks for charities (watch the video).

item.title: The little things in films can make a big difference
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I listen to a lot of podcasts (probably 500+ a year) and one I make an extra effort to listen to every episode is 99% Invisible. It is "about all the thought that goes into the things we don’t think about — the unnoticed architecture and design that shape our world."

item.title: Rewarding the act of volunteering
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: A new digital coin has been introduced in Hull to reward people who volunteer for things. Due to regulations the receiver can cash in their coin in the form of a discount when purchasing products at certain stores.

item.title: Surprising the customer with unexpected pricing
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Derek Sivers highlights an interesting pricing approach in this article. He was asked to perform at a distant location. When the customer couldn't afford the price they suggested reducing the performance time, hoping to reduce the price. Instead of doing the expected he raised his price. His reason was that they were paying for him to get to the location and then do the work where the work was the fun bit. By reducing the time on the fun bit it was less worth him making the trip.

item.title: The alternative bucket list approach to life
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I have never formally made a bucket list. Sure, there are things I would love to do and some more than others but I have never written anything down.

item.title: Knowledge workers are assets not costs
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: This is an excellent article that touches on some many areas including Amazon (again) and their structure. However the most interesting part for me is the section on the way to view knowledge workers in business:

item.title: Taking the pain out of logo design with Tailor Brands
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: I came across a link on Product Hunt to Tailor Brands who do automatic logo creation and branding. It is great to see them still doing well. I used them for my company logo, Sentio Ventures, shortly after they started in 2014!

item.title: Blockchain - what impact will it have?
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: There are a lot of stories around how Blockchain could revolutionize every industry. This is a nice summary of some of the companies that are trying to make this happen and the way they are trying to make an impact.

item.title: Could Amazon revolutionize the shopping experience?
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: Amazon just opened the first store with no cashiers or checkouts.

item.title: Technology - Am I past it?
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: This is an interesting post from Rob Conery, someone I've followed for quite some time, and his observations as he gets older about how he wonders if he is past keeping up with new technology.

item.title: Getting started with the Hugo static site generator
item.author: Mark Rainey
item.description: This blog is being powered by a static content generator called Hugo and hosted on GitHub Pages. Getting Hugo up and running was relatively easy. Download the relevant version and installation was just copying it to a folder.
